body:
I think I'm getting a similar error (if not will raise a new ticket).  I'm on the latest beta (rclone v1.41-109-gd9d00a7dÎ²)

```
2018/06/15 22:17:14 INFO : cache: Connected to Plex server: https://192.168.30.90:32400
2018/06/15 22:17:17 ERROR : plex: websocket.Dial wss://192.168.30.90:32400/:/websockets/notifications?X-Plex-Token=REDACTED: dial tcp 192.168.30.90:32400: connect: no route to host
```

I have secure connections in plex set to Preferred.  I've tried https and http with no joy and I've also tried my LE domain my-domain.com/plex to no avail.

Plex is running on the same server in a docker as the rclone mount

@remusb its not resolved. The issue is that if you put in any IP, or DNS other than the one that is generated by plex (for example, https://172-24-0-4.b4cxxxxxxxxxxxxxx0dd3.plex.direct:32400 which I was able to obtain from Tautulli) the websocket thinks that the certificate is invalid because the IP/DNS you are using does not match the one that Plex generated the cert for. 

This is not an issue w/ regular http and works fine if you have Plex configured on Preferred or Disabled because it will still listen on http, however I don't really want to risk sending any information over http these days. 

See logs below of my trial and error ;P

```
2018/09/03 23:33:53 INFO  : gcache: Connected to Plex server: https://localhost:32400
2018/09/03 23:33:53 ERROR : plex: websocket.Dial wss://localhost:32400/:/websockets/notifications?X-Plex-Token=asdfasdf: x509: certificate is valid for *.b4cxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx0dd3.plex.direct, not localhost
```
^ same goes for 127.0.0.1



```
2018/09/03 23:41:50 INFO  : gcache: Connected to Plex server: https://156.5.55.145:32400
2018/09/03 23:41:50 ERROR : plex: websocket.Dial wss://156.5.55.145:32400/:/websockets/notifications?X-Plex-Token=asdfasdf: x509: cannot validate certificate for 156.5.55.145 because it doesn't contain any IP SANs
```
^ not real IP of course.... but you get the gist.

You can use the https://172-24-0-4.b4cxxxxxxxxxxxxxx0dd3.plex.direct:32400/ address to get validated https connections. The IP in the front of the url is not fixed an can be changed.
```
https://127-0-0-1.b4cxxxxxxxxxxxxxx0dd3.plex.direct:32400/
https://156-5-55-145.b4cxxxxxxxxxxxxxx0dd3.plex.direct:32400/
https://192-168-0-100.b4cxxxxxxxxxxxxxx0dd3.plex.direct:32400/
```
These are all valid addresses which will pass certificate validation.

To find this address you can go to https://plex.tv/api/resources?includeHttps=1&X-Plex-Token=123456789 and see the values for all you plex servers.

You can use the https://172-24-0-4.b4cxxxxxxxxxxxxxx0dd3.plex.direct:32400/ address to get validated https connections. The IP in the front of the url is not fixed an can be changed.
```
https://127-0-0-1.b4cxxxxxxxxxxxxxx0dd3.plex.direct:32400/
https://156-5-55-145.b4cxxxxxxxxxxxxxx0dd3.plex.direct:32400/
https://192-168-0-100.b4cxxxxxxxxxxxxxx0dd3.plex.direct:32400/
```
These are all valid addresses which will pass certificate validation.

To find this address you can go to https://plex.tv/api/resources?includeHttps=1&X-Plex-Token=123456789 and see the values for all you plex servers.
@B4dM4n - is this something which should go in the cache docs?

Finding these `.plex.direct` URL's is pretty hard if you don't know what exactly you are looking for.
I can write a little explanation how to get and use them.
Is it worth investigating a software solution to the problem?

issue.title: docs: add section for .plex.direct urls to cache

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body: A discussed in #2215, this adds a section to the cache docs to explain the usage of `.plex.direct` URL's.

issue.title: cache: add plex_insecure option to skip certificate validation

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
As requested in #2215, this adds a `plex_insecure` config setting to the cache backend, which will turn off all certificate verification's when connecting to the Plex server.

Fixes #2215

body:
I created two PR's regarding this issue.

One documenting the `.plex.direct` URL's and one to actually implement a `plex_insecure` setting to skip all certificate validation.
